initial_story:
Firefighters and police were seen outside the office of Mike Freer MP

Police are investigating a suspected arson attack at the office of North London Conservative MP Mike Freer.

A fire broke out at the rear of the North Finchley and Golders Green MP's constituency office at around 19:00 on Christmas Eve.

The Met Police confirmed it is investigating the fire.

Mr Freer told the BBC the fire happened at the rear of the premises and no one was in the building at the time of the incident.

He continued: "The police and fire brigade were on the scene in minutes and have been incredible in their response."

London Fire Brigade (LFB) confirmed the fire started in a shed outside the office before spreading to the rest of the building.

An LFB spokesperson said: "An external shed was destroyed by fire. Part of the first, second and third floors of the property were also damaged by the blaze."

In a statement, a Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: "The cause of the fire is under investigation as it is believed it may have been started deliberately. There have been no arrests."

Pictures posted on social media showed Metropolitan Police and LFB vehicles at the premises on Sunday evening.

Mr Freer has represented the North London constituency since 2010.

He is parliamentary under-secretary of state for courts and legal services, a junior role in the Ministry of Justice.

Pictures show the fire spread to an office inside the building
stories:
Detectives and forensic experts swarmed the campaign headquarters of Councilwoman Sarah Lee yesterday evening, following a suspected act of vandalism that left the building's facade shattered and its interior badly damaged.

The incident occurred around 22:00, when witnesses reported hearing the sound of breaking glass and seeing a figure fleeing the scene. Authorities confirmed that no one was injured in the attack, but the office's front door and several windows were smashed, with debris scattered across the sidewalk.

Councilwoman Lee, a vocal advocate for community development and social justice, expressed shock and dismay at the attack, saying "This senseless act of destruction will not intimidate me or deter me from serving the people of this great city."

Preliminary investigation suggests that the perpetrator used a heavy object to shatter the windows and door, with police reviewing security footage to identify the suspect. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but authorities are exploring possible links to recent controversies surrounding Councilwoman Lee's policies on affordable housing and police reform.

As the city's residents rallied around Councilwoman Lee, condemning the attack and pledging support, officials vowed to bring the perpetrator to justice and ensure that the democratic process is protected from such acts of intimidation.

Activists and journalists converged on the independent newspaper office of editor-in-chief, Maria Rodriguez, last night, following a suspected act of arson that left the building's roof charred and its newsroom badly damaged.

The incident occurred around 02:00, when witnesses reported seeing flames engulfing the roof and a figure fleeing the scene on a motorcycle. Firefighters confirmed that no one was injured in the blaze, but the office's archives and equipment were destroyed, with smoke damage affecting the entire building.

Maria Rodriguez, a renowned investigative journalist and vocal critic of government corruption, expressed outrage and defiance at the attack, saying "This cowardly act of sabotage will not silence me or deter me from exposing the truth to the people of this city."

Preliminary investigation suggests that the perpetrator used an accelerant to start the fire, with police reviewing security footage to identify the suspect. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but authorities are exploring possible links to recent exposés by Rodriguez's newspaper on government embezzlement and police brutality.

As the city's press corps rallied around Rodriguez, condemning the attack and pledging support, officials vowed to bring the perpetrator to justice and ensure that freedom of the press is protected from such acts of intimidation.
